channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: As E.U. Meets, Crimea Moves to Hold Vote on Joining Russia
item.description: European leaders on Thursday were seeking to reinforce their support for Ukraine’s government, as pro-Russian authorities in Crimea pressed ahead with plans to break away from Ukraine and become part of Russia.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Tunisia Ends Emergency Rule
item.description: President Moncef Marzouki lifted the state of emergency that had been in force since the country’s 2011 uprising.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: March 6
item.description: Vehicles to be used for political campaign in the upcoming general election are given final touches in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Workers in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh, giving final touches to vehicles which would be used for political campaign in the upcoming general elections due in April-May.

item.title: Rooting for Wrong Cricket Team? That’s Sedition, Kashmiri Students Learn
item.description: The police in northern India filed charges against 67 students after some cheered for the Pakistani cricket team in a televised match with India.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: From left, Gulzar Ahmed, Muteebul Majid and Aijaz Bhat are among the 67 Kashmiri students suspended from their university in India for cheering for the Pakistani cricket team.

item.title: U.S. Escalates Sanction Response in Ukraine Crisis
item.description: The State Department imposed a ban on visas for people who have taken steps to undermine Ukraine’s territorial integrity, and Russia vowed to reciprocate.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: India Ink: A Victory over Bollywood for Underdog, then It’s Snatched Away
item.description: The leader of the crusading women’s group in rural Uttar Pradesh succeeded in getting a court to delay the release of a movie she contends is based on her life story, but then hours later, the ruling was reversed.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Madhuri Dixit, a Bollywood actress who played the protagonist in the film, 'Gulaab Gang' at an awards function in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on March 1.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Goes Quiet on Rise of Local Security Budgets
item.description: Saying the data “is still being collected,” the Chinese Finance Ministry has declined to release figures on local security spending, a major component of a domestic security apparatus that has grown bigger than the military.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A security camera watching in front of the Chinese national emblem on the Great Hall of the People, where sessions of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference and National People's Congress were underway.

item.title: Sevastopol Journal: Steeped in Bloody History, and Seeing a Chance to Rewrite It
item.description: It has been half a century since Crimea was lopped from Russia and attached to Ukraine, but for many on the peninsula, it may as well have been yesterday.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: People in Sevastopol, Ukraine gathered for a pro-Russia rally on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: How to Woo Muslim Voters in Uttar Pradesh
item.description: Gaining the support of Muslims in the politically important state requires a more complex strategy than just fielding a candidate of the same religion.
item.dc:creator: By SONIA PAUL
item.media:description: Men cheering for Narendra Modi, the prime ministerial candidate of Bharatiya Janata Party, at his rally in Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh, on Mar. 2.

item.title: U.S. Airstrike Kills 5 Afghan Soldiers
item.description: Eight others were wounded in the attack in the Charkh district of Logar Province, and local officials attributed it to a drone strike.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: U.S. Airstrike Kills 5 Afghan Soldiers
item.description: Eight others were wounded in the attack in the Charkh district of Logar Province, and local officials attributed it to a drone strike.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: European Central Bank Holds Rates Steady
item.description: The central bank kept its benchmark interest rate at 0.25 percent, still betting that the euro zone can avoid a ruinous downward price spiral.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank. On Thursday the bank left its benchmark interest rate at 0.25 percent, which is a record low.

item.title: Bank of England Keeps Benchmark Rate at Record Low
item.description: Britain’s central bank said it would keep its key interest rate at 0.5 percent, where it has been since March 2009. The bank also left its bond purchasing program unchanged.
item.dc:creator: By JENNY ANDERSON

item.title: Letter From Europe: The Long Memories Shared by Britain and South Africa
item.description: Two far-flung events — a Nelson Mandela memorial and the trial of Oscar Pistorius — illustrate the curious links between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius at his trial in Pretoria on Thursday.

item.title: Niger Extradites a Son of Qaddafi to Libya
item.description: Saadi el-Qaddafi faces accusations of participating in the corruption and abuses of his father’s 40 years in power.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Blowing Away the Smog in Beijing, Politically Speaking
item.description: The annual sessions of the National People’s Congress and the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Conference are underway in Beijing, and both groups are regarded by many Chinese as not truly representative of the people.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Hostesses who serve the delegates to the National People's Congress and Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference posed for souvenir photos in front of the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

item.title: North Korea Rejects Plans for More Family Reunions
item.description: Pyongyang’s decision not to hold Red Cross talks on more reunions with South Korea comes as it has been launching missiles and rockets, further heightening tensions.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Charges Dropped Against Briton Accused of Transmitting Tennis Scores
item.description: The 22-yerar-old man was the first to face criminal charges over conduct intended to corrupt the outcome of bets on matches at the Australian Open.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS and GERRY MULLANY

item.title: One Goal in Hand, Kiev’s Demonstrators Vow to Stay ‘Until the End’
item.description: The end for Ukraine’s demonstrators has proved elusive, even after their surprise victory last month, and Independence Square and its surrounding streets remain a nationalist encampment.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS

item.title: U.S. Effort to Broker Russia-Ukraine Diplomacy Fails
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry and his Russian counterpart said there would be more discussions, as the European Union offered aid worth as much as $15 billion over the next two years.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Point by Point, State Department Rebuts Putin on Ukraine
item.description: The State Department bluntly listed “10 False Claims About Ukraine” it said President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had made in a news conference.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Mystery Men at De Facto Crimean Border Help Fuel Suspicion and Dread
item.description: Soldiers gathered at the sliver of land separating Crimea and the rest of Ukraine leave little doubt that they have dug in for the long haul.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Pope Moves to Deflate Breathless Portrayals of Stardom
item.description: Ahead of the first anniversary of his election to the papacy, Francis used a newspaper interview to depict himself as a normal person.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: An Evacuation of Jews, With Help From Japan
item.description: As Japan Week begins in New York City, a video about the roles of a diplomat and a tourist-bureau employee in saving Jews from the Nazis will be shown at Grand Central Terminal on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES BARRON
item.media:description: Akira Kitade with the scrapbook of Tatsuo Osako.

item.title: For Russian TV Channels, Influence and Criticism
item.description: Russia’s government-operated networks are led by executives who have helped promote President Vladimir V. Putin’s agenda, but they are facing fact-checking over coverage of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia leading a cabinet meeting on Wednesday near Moscow.
